bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 9, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean discusses her decision to stay in Cuba and her life at the post. In a postscript she mentions the excitement surrounding the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 9, 1900
div1.p:
I got dreadfully
mixed up on the
mail days and am
so sorry you have gone
a week without a
letter. Tho' Rannie wrote
you by the last boat
I think- I have been
thinking how you will feel
when you get that
letter. I know you will
be disappointed, for your
two letters were so
sweet and of course you
thought that we
would go north when
the order was issued-
But Rannie has written
you all the whys and
wherefores, so I will
not repeat them- I
wish we were going
back so as to see you
and a great many
other reasons, but I must
confess I am not sorry
to spend this winter in
Cuba, now I am down
here. It is perfectly
lovely in every way-
The weather is perfect and the
post charming. Everybody is most
kind in saying they hope the orders
for McHenry will be revoked. We are
still in the cottage, but I think will
probably move up into “Major's Row”
early next week, for Dr. Havard is
going away on leave very soon, then
Rannie will be the acting Chief Surgeon
and the change around among the
Post Surgeons will be delayed a month
or six weeks.

I intended to write you a nice,
long letter when I started, but we
have had a string of callers, until
it is so late it is time to go
to bed, and my long letter will
have to wait until next time.

Bobbie is so sweet and so well
I just long every day to show him
to you. His cheeks are like roses
and he laughs and grins at every
body that speaks to
him. He is much
admired by the men
and women both.

Mrs. Jackson gave a
party for the Gen. last
night. A select few
were honored with in-
vitations, the Keans be-
ing among the victims.
It was a slow stupid
affair tho' I sat in
the hammock with Mr.
Day and made the
best of it. Now Mrs.
Stark and I are going
to try our hands at
a party, to be given
Wednesday afternoon-
I will write you our
plans later on.

Please send me my
Virginia cook book and
the parasol to Bobbie's
carriage. You wrote as
tho' I had left a
good many things
behind, you had better
send them along I think.

I will surely get you
off a nice letter in
the next mail, so
with love to Marie
and all the family.
div1.closer:
Very lovingly Louise. Dr. Reed has come back, and every-
body is crazy about the mosquito
theory, the garrison hardly talks of
anything else, and they all take
such an interest in killing the
mosquitoes with kerosene there is
scarcely one on the post.
